title: Clutton-Tabenor FRED
text:
The Clutton-Tabenor FRED is a British <a href="homebuilt%20aircraft">homebuilt aircraft</a> design introduced in 1963.
Design and development.
The <a href="prototype">prototype</a> FRED (Flying Runabout Experimental Design) was designed and built by E.C. Clutton and E.W. Sherry between 1957 and 1963. The aircraft, registered "G-ASZY", first flew at <a href="Meir%2C%20Staffordshire">Meir</a> aerodrome, <a href="Stoke-on-Trent">Stoke-on-Trent</a> on 3 November 1963. It was a single-seat wood and fabric <a href="Parasol%20wing">parasol monoplane</a> powered originally by a <a href="List%20of%20Triumph%20motorcycles%23Post-war">Triumph 5T</a> motorcycle engine. By 1968 it was flying with a converted <a href="Volkswagen%20air%20cooled%20engine">Volkswagen engine</a>. The <a href="Continental%20A-65">Continental A-65</a> <a href="four%20stroke">four stroke</a> powerplant has also been used. The plans were made available to allow the aircraft to be homebuilt and thirty to forty examples have been built around the world.
